definition:
Let $A$ be a set and $R$ be a relation on $A$. Suppose that $B$ is a
subset of $A$. An element $a\in B$ is said to be [**$R$-minimal in
$B$**]{} if and only if there is no $x\in B$ such that $xRa$. An
$R$-minimal element in $A$ is simply called [**$R$-minimal**]{}.

From this definition, it is evident that if $A$ has an $R$-minimal
element, then $R$ is not reflexive. However, the definition of
$R$-minimality is sometimes adjusted slightly so as to allow
reflexivity: $a\in B$ is $R$-minimal (in $B$) iff the only $x\in B$ such
that $xRa$ is when $x=a$.

**Remark**. Using the second definition, it is easy to see that when $R$
is a partial order, then an element $a$ is $R$-minimal iff it is
minimal.
